Title.evidence: High-Quality Implementation of the Surgical Safety Checklist: A Stepped Wedge Cluster Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The unit of randomisation was surgical specialties, with a sample size calculation requiring a minimum of 1100 patients per group.

Participants.evidence: Participants included patients undergoing orthopedic, cardiothoracic, and neurosurgical procedures.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention was the SSC, and the comparator was standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the impact of high-quality implementation of the World Health Organization's Surgical Safety Checklist (SSC) on care processes and patient outcomes in two Norwegian hospitals.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was in-hospital complications, measured over a 3-month period post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through a draw of numbers, with allocation concealment by blinding the allocation assessor.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 3702 procedures were analysed (1398 control, 2304 intervention).

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 3702 procedures were analysed (1398 control, 2304 intervention).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The odds ratio for surgical infections was 0.52 (95% CI: 0.38–0.72) for intervention procedures.
